thinking.disposable_income: Greater Heights residents have relatively high disposable income with median household income around $110,000, indicating capacity to absorb moderate transportation cost increases.
thinking.discretionary_consumption: The neighborhood has high discretionary spending power evidenced by numerous boutique shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues, suggesting residents can manage higher taxes and fees.
thinking.accessibility: The area has good road access but limited transit options, with most residents relying on cars while having interest in better transit connectivity to downtown and other employment centers.
thinking.decision_rationale: 1) Prioritized balanced proposals that improve transit service while keeping driving viable given current car dependency. 2) Selected moderate tax rates (1.0-1.5%) that can fund transit improvements without excessive burden on high discretionary spending. 3) Favored proposals with $0.75-$1.25 transit fares to encourage ridership. 4) Included modest driving fees ($0.50-$1.00) to manage congestion while reflecting ability to pay. 5) Focused on options that reduce both transit and driving times significantly from current levels.
